deliberation: Checked for metaphors, idioms, and personification. The key non-literal element is the 'spirit' lifting and bringing Ezekiel, depicting the divine Spirit as an active moving force. This is conventional prophetic language but still personifies the ruach. The rest (place names, number of men, titles) is straightforward narrative.

instances.explanation: The divine Spirit (רוּחַ) is depicted as an agent that can physically lift and carry Ezekiel, personifying the Spirit as a mover rather than describing a merely inner feeling.

deliberation: The verse labels the men as those who 'plan iniquity' and 'give evil counsel.' These are literal descriptions of their moral and political activity, not figurative expressions; no metaphors, idioms, or personifications are present.

Looked for slogans, metaphors, and idioms. The clause about not building houses is debated but likely a straightforward assertion. The explicit copular statements 'she is the pot' and 'we are the meat' are two linked but distinct metaphors: Jerusalem as a pot, the people as meat protected inside it.

instances.explanation: The speakers equate Jerusalem with a cooking pot, implying it is a secure container that will protect those inside from the 'fire' of external danger.

deliberation: Command to prophesy, with vocative 'son of man / mortal.' This is standard prophetic diction and vocative, not figurative in itself in this context. No metaphors, similes, or idioms beyond normal address formula.

Examined 'spirit of YHWH fell upon me' and 'ascents of your spirit.' Both construe non-physical realities through physical imagery. The Spirit 'falling' is personification of divine inspiration as a descending force. 'Ascents of your spirit' is a metaphor for inner thoughts rising up.

deliberation: This verse deliberately turns the pot/meat slogan of v.3 against the leaders. It repeats the pot/meat imagery but now applies 'meat' to the corpses and states that those addressed will be removed. There are two copular metaphors: corpses as meat and city as pot, used in ironic reversal.

instances.explanation: God reassigns the leaders’ own image, calling the slain (not the leaders) the 'meat', thus ironically exposing the deadly consequences of their policies.

instances.explanation: The city is again likened to a pot, but instead of guaranteeing safety, it is the vessel in which the 'meat' (the slain) undergoes the destructive process of judgment, undercutting the leaders’ earlier sense of security.

deliberation: The verse negates the pot/meat imagery but still relies on the same metaphoric mapping from v.3 and v.7. 'It will not be for you as a pot' and 'you will be in it [not] as meat' are two metaphorical predications, now denied to overturn their slogan.

deliberation: The narrative death of Pelatiah is literal within the vision. The cry 'Are you making a full end of the remnant of Israel?' likely uses 'making a full end' as rhetorical exaggeration expressing fear of total annihilation. This functions as hyperbolic language of lament, even if Ezekiel genuinely fears it.

deliberation: The formula 'the word of YHWH came to me' is standard prophetic diction that personifies God’s message as something that 'comes.' It is conventional but still a figurative representation of revelation.

deliberation: Examined 'scattered among the countries' and 'a little sanctuary.' Scattering is literal exile imagery. 'I have been to them a little sanctuary in the countries' is clearly metaphorical: God himself is described as a 'sanctuary' for the exiles, not a physical building.

deliberation: Gathering from the peoples and giving the land of Israel are central restoration promises that can be taken quite literally in the exilic context. While 'gather' often has metaphorical resonance (like gathering sheep), here it most naturally denotes actual regathering from exile; I do not isolate a distinct figurative expression.

The verse speaks of removing 'detestable things' and 'abominations'—standard terms for idols and cult objects. Though evaluative, they are not figurative here but refer directly to illicit religious items/practices. No clear metaphor or idiom beyond conventional value language.

This verse is rich in inner-life metaphors: 'one heart,' 'new spirit,' 'heart of stone,' 'heart of flesh.' These construe inner disposition in bodily terms and contrast hardness vs. responsiveness. I group 'one heart/new spirit' as one metaphor of unified, renewed will, and treat the 'heart of stone' vs 'heart of flesh' pair as another, more specific metaphor.

deliberation: Describes elements of Ezekiel’s vision: cherubs, wheels, wings, and the glory of the God of Israel above them. Within the visionary framework, these are not functioning as figures of speech but as components of a symbolic vision; no separate figurative wording is singled out here.

Here 'the glory of YHWH' goes up from the midst of the city and stands on the mountain to the east. In Ezekiel, 'glory' is a radiant manifestation but is still an abstract quality treated as a moving, standing entity; this personifies God’s glory as if it were a mobile person or object.

deliberation: Again, the 'spirit' lifts and brings Ezekiel in a vision, mirroring v.1. This portrays the divine Spirit as an active carrier. Within the narrative, it is visionary transport but linguistically it personifies the ruach as a moving agent.

deliberation: Narrates Ezekiel speaking to the exiles all the words of YHWH that God had shown him. Though 'words' being 'shown' blends vision and speech, in context it summarizes the combined visionary-message experience rather than functioning as a discrete figure of speech. No clear, isolated figurative expression is detected.
